{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}} {{Use British English|date=January 2014}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = [[The Right Honourable]] | name = The Lord Allen of Kensington | honorific_suffix = {{Post-nominals|country=GBR|CBE|size=100%}} | birth_date = {{Birth-date and age|df=yes|4 January 1957}} | birth_place = [[Lanarkshire]], Scotland{{cite news|title=The Charles Allen years |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2006/aug/08/citynews.television1 |newspaper=The Guardian |date=8 August 2006 |accessdate=4 June 2015}} | nationality = British | residence = Kensington, London | occupation = Businessman and broadcaster | years_active = 1991–present | title = [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of [[Granada plc|Granada Group]] (1996–2000)
[[Non-executive director|Non-exec. director]] of [[Tesco|Tesco plc]] (1999–2010){{cite web|title=Board of Directors|work=[[Tesco]]|url=http://ar2010.tescoplc.com/a-business-for-a-new-decade/board-of-directors.aspx|accessdate=1 November 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110910051502/http://ar2010.tescoplc.com/a-business-for-a-new-decade/board-of-directors.aspx|archivedate=10 September 2011}}
[[Chairman|Exec. chairman]] of Granada Media plc (2000–04)
CEO of [[ITV plc]] (2004–07)
Chairman of [[Global Radio]] (2007–present)
Exec. chairman of [[EMI]] (2008–10)
Chairman of Executive Board of the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] (March 2012-2015)
Chairman of [[British Red Cross]] (2013–2014)
Chairman of [[ISS A/S]] (2013–present) }} '''Charles Lamb Allen, Baron Allen of Kensington''', {{Post-nominals|country=GBR|CBE|size=100%|sep=,}} (born 4 January 1957) is a British businessman and broadcaster, and the chairman of [[Global Radio]], [[2 Sisters Food Group]], ISS and Advisory chairman at [[Moelis & Company]]. Lord Allen was chief executive of [[Granada plc|Granada Group]] from 1996 to 2000, executive chairman of Granada Media plc from 2000 to 2004, chief executive of [[ITV plc]] from its formation in 2004 until 2007, and chairman of the music company [[EMI]]. He was chairman of Endemol, a non-executive director of Tesco plc and Virgin Media. In March 2012, he was appointed by [[Ed Miliband]], the leader of the Labour Party, to the position of chairman of the executive board of the party. He has been chairman of the [[British Red Cross]]. ==Education== Allen was educated at Bellshill Academy,{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2005/dec/09/citynews.television|title=Charles Allen: a survivor in the minefield of the media|work=[[The Guardian]]|author=Jane Martinson|date=9 December 2005|accessdate=4 October 2016}} a state school in the town of [[Bellshill]] in [[North Lanarkshire]] in central Scotland. He did not attend university, and says of his life, "It's been an amazing journey considering I left school at 17 with no job to go to".{{cite web|url=http://www.director.co.uk/2-2958-lord-allen-global-radio-chairman-mentor-tormentor|title=Global Radio chairman Lord Allen on Brexit, boardrooms and the BBC|work=Director.co.uk|author=Richard Dunnett|date=5 January 2016|accessdate=4 October 2016}} ==Television== Allen joined [[Granada plc]] in 1991, originally as CEO of [[ITV Granada|Granada Television]], before becoming Group Chief Executive in 1996. During his time at Granada, he was instrumental in the takeover of [[Forte Group]] for £3.9 billion in 1996, and the takeovers of [[London Weekend Television|LWT]] and [[Yorkshire-Tyne Tees Television]] in 1994 and 1999 respectively. In 2001 Granada Group merged with Compass to form Granada Compass, then demerged into Granada Media plc and Compass Group. He remained with Granada when the two companies demerged, and became Executive Chairman of Granada plc in 2001. When Granada merged with [[Carlton Communications]] in 2004 to form ITV plc, Allen became the new company's [[Chief executive officer|Chief Executive]].[http://www.itvplc.com/itv/about/board/#allen ITV plc] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061128182216/http://www.itvplc.com/itv/about/board/#allen |date=28 November 2006 }}, accessed 6 July 2006. In 2006, Allen stepped down after fifteen years with the company.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/jan/16/itv-emi-charles-allen|title=Charles Allen: a survivor in the minefield of the media|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=16 January 2009}} ==Other interests== From 2006 to 2008, Allen was previously Chief Advisor to the British Home Office. He has also been a Senior Advisor to Goldman Sachs Private Equity, non-executive director of [[Endemol]] and [[Virgin Media]] and executive Chairman of [[EMI]].{{cite web|url=https://www.parliament.uk/biographies/lords/lord-allen-of-kensington/4304|website=UK Parliament|title=Lord Allen of Kensington}} As of 2018, he is Chairman of ISS Group, [[2 Sisters Food Group]] and [[Global Group]] — which owns Capital, Heart, Classic FM, LBC, Radio X and Gold — as well as advisory Chairman of [[Moelis & Company]]. Allen chaired the [[2002 Commonwealth Games]]. He was a member of the [[2012_Summer_Olympics|London 2012]] Olympic bid team and a Director of the London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games. He was also Mayor of the [[Olympic Park, London|Olympic Village]]. ==Honours== Allen was appointed a [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] (CBE) in the [[2003 New Year Honours]] "for services to the [[2002 Commonwealth Games|XVII Commonwealth Games]]".{{London Gazette |issue=56797 |date=31 December 2002 |page=7 |supp=y }} He was [[Knight Bachelor|knighted]] in the [[2012 New Year Honours]] "for services to the [[2012 Summer Olympics|2012 Olympics]] and [[2012 Summer Paralympics|Paralympics]]".{{London Gazette |issue=60009 |date=31 December 2011 |page=1 |supp=y}}{{London Gazette |issue=60245 |date=21 August 2012 |page=16079}} On 1 August 2013, it was announced that Allen was to become a Labour peer in a list of new appointments to the House of Lords.{{cite news|last=Craig |first=Jon |url=http://news.sky.com/story/1123153/jcb-boss-sir-anthony-bamford-made-tory-peer |title=JCB Boss Sir Anthony Bamford Made Tory Peer |publisher=Sky News |date=2013-08-01 |accessdate=2013-11-01}} He was created a [[Life Peer]] on 2 October 2013 taking the title '''Baron Allen of Kensington''', of [[Kensington]] in the [[Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea]].{{London Gazette |issue=60648 |date=4 October 2013 |page=19575}} In May 2016, Allen was appointed as a member of the Lords Communications Committee. In 2005 he was awarded the Freedom of the City of Liverpool.{{cite news|title=Business Diary|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/comment/citydiary/2923753/Business-diary.html|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=13 October 2005}} ==Personal life== Allen lives in Kensington with his partner of more than 20 years, Michael, an architect.{{cute news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/lord-allen-putting-an-obsessive-attitude-to-work-and-making-it-pay-9195868.html|title=Lord Allen: Putting an obsessive attitude to work – and making it pay|work=[[The Independent]]|date=16 March 2014}} == References == {{reflist|2}} {{s-start}} {{succession box|title=Chief Executive of [[ITV plc]]|before=None|after=[[Michael Grade]]
(Executive chairman)|years=2004–06}} {{s-end}} {{International Emmy Directorate Award}} {{Global Radio}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Allen, Charles}} [[Category:ITV people]] [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:LGBT businesspeople from the United Kingdom]] [[Category:LGBT politicians from Scotland]] [[Category:LGBT life peers]] [[Category:Labour Party (UK) life peers]] [[Category:LGBT people from Scotland]] [[Category:Scottish businesspeople]] [[Category:Knights Bachelor]] [[Category:Commanders of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:Labour Party (UK) officials]] [[Category:International Emmy Directorate Award]]

{{Infobox person | name = Charles Eugène Bedaux | image = Charles Bedaux and filmakers.gif | image_size = | caption = Bedaux with his film crew in Canada in 1934 | birth_date = 26 October 1886 | birth_place = [[Paris, France]] | death_date = 18 February 1944 | death_place = [[Miami, Florida]] | education = | occupation = Production Engineer and Management Consultant | spouse = Fern | parents = | children = }} '''Charles Eugène Bedaux''' (10 October 1886 – 18 February 1944) was a [[France|French]]-born American [[millionaire]] who made his fortune developing and implementing the [[work measurement]] aspect of [[scientific management]], notably the [[Bedaux System]]. Considered one of the most eccentric [[millionaire]]s of the early twentieth century, Bedaux was friends with [[British royalty]] and [[Nazism|Nazis]] alike, and was a [[management consultant]], [[big game hunter]] and [[explorer]].
==Early years== Charles Bedaux was born in the [[Charenton-le-Pont]] [[commune]] of [[Paris, France]].<ref name=KreisADNB>Steven Kreis, 'Charles E. Bedaux' in ''[[American National Biography]]'' [http://oxfordindex.oup.com/view/10.1093/anb/9780198606697.article.1000116 online]</ref> Little is known about his early life but his brother Gaston later recorded that in 1903, Charles dropped out of [[Lycée Jean-Baptiste-Say]] in [[Paris]] where he had been studying engineering.
Charles worked a series of menial jobs before befriending Henri Ledoux, a successful [[pimp]] from the infamous [[Quartier Pigalle|Pigalle]] district. The mysterious Ledoux apparently taught Bedaux lessons on proper dress, confidence and street-fighting, but was murdered in 1906.<ref name=Gaston>Gaston Bedaux, ''La Vie Ardente de Charles Bedaux'' (1959)</ref>
What is verified is that in 1906, Charles moved to the United States, where he became a [[United States citizen]], married, and had a son, Charles Emile Bedaux (1909–1993).<ref name=KreisADNB /> He would later claim in interviews to have worked as a restaurant bottle-washer, a [[sandhog]],<ref>'Duke's Guide Here had Vivid Rise; Industrialist Began as Laborer' ''New York Times'', 24 October 1937. [https://www.nytimes.com/1937/10/24/archives/dukes-guide-here-had-vivid-rise-industrialist-began-as-laborer.html ''New York Times'' online archive]</ref> and at the [[New Jersey]] Worsted Mills in [[Hoboken, New Jersey|Hoboken]].<ref name=KreisADNB />
==The Bedaux B== Bedaux was one of the leading contributors in the field of [[work measurement]] or ''labor measurement'', one strand of the [[scientific management]] movement's influence. In this, he was strongly influenced by [[Frederick Winslow Taylor|F.W. Taylor]]'s book ''Shop Management'',<ref>See F.W. Taylor, ''Shop Management'' (Harper & Brothers, 1911). Online at [https://archive.org/details/shopmanagement01tayl Archive.org]</ref> particularly Taylor's time study practices, and [[Charles Edward Knoeppel|Charles E. Knoeppel]]'s writings on industrial layout and routing.<ref name=Brech>[[Edward Francis Leopold Brech]], ''Productivity in Perspective, 1914-1974'' (Bristol: Thoemmes Press, 2002).</ref><ref name=Weatherburn>Michael R. Weatherburn, 'Scientific Management at Work: the Bedaux System, Management Consulting, and Worker Efficiency in British Industry, 1914-48' (Imperial College PhD thesis, 2014). {{cite web|url= https://spiral.imperial.ac.uk/handle/10044/1/25296 |title=Download PDF from Imperial College, London }}</ref>
[[File:The_Bedaux_company_logo,_featuring_the_"B".jpg|thumb|left|The Bedaux company logo, featuring its distinctive "B" unit]]
Building on these authors, Bedaux introduced the concept of rating assessment, which led to improvements in the comparability of employee and departmental efficiency. He named this the "[[Bedaux System|Bedaux System of Human Power Measurement]]." The distinguishing feature of the Bedaux System, which advanced it beyond these earlier scientific management practitioners, was in its use of the ''[[Bedaux Unit]]'' or ''B'', a universal measure for all manual work.<ref name=Brech /><ref name=Littler>Craig R. Littler, ''Development of the Labour Process in Capitalist Societies: a Comparative Study of the Transformation of Work Organization in Britain, Japan and the USA'' (London: Heinemann, 1982) [https://books.google.com/books/about/The_development_of_the_labour_process_in.html?id=2k2yAAAAIAAJ entry on Google Books]</ref>
Bedaux also mimicked [[Frank Gilbreth]] by introducing a [[time and motion study|motion study]] [[Kodascope]] package which he propagated with an early Bedaux client, [[Eastman Kodak|Kodak]].<ref name=KreisThesis>Steven Kreis, 'The Diffusion of an Idea: A History of Scientific Management in Britain, 1890-1945' (PhD thesis, University of Missouri-Columbia, 1990) [http://www.worldcat.org/title/diffusion-of-an-idea-a-history-of-scientific-management-in-britain-1890-1945/oclc/25526850?referer=di&ht=edition entry on WorldCat]</ref>
==Management consultancy== Bedaux became associated with one of Taylor's circle, [[Harrington Emerson]], whose consultancy, [[Emerson Consulting]],<ref>William F. Muhs, 'The Emerson Engineers: A Look at One of the First Management Consulting Firms in the U.S' ''Academy of Management Proceedings'' Vol. 1986, No. 1 (1986). [http://proceedings.aom.org/content/1986/1/123.short Academy of Management Proceedings]</ref><ref>James Quigel, 'The Business of Selling Efficiency: Harrington Emerson and the Emerson Efficiency Engineers, 1900-1930 (PhD thesis, Pennsylvania State University, 1992). [http://www.worldcat.org/title/business-of-selling-efficiency-harrington-emerson-and-the-emerson-efficiency-engineers-1900-1930/oclc/71800992/editions?referer=di&editionsView=true entry on WorldCat]</ref> Bedaux emulated in sectors additional to engineering.<ref name="Link">Steven Kreis, 'The Diffusion of Scientific Management: the Bedaux Company in America and Britain, 1926-1945' in ''A Mental Revolution: Scientific Management Since Taylor'' (1992) {{cite web|url= https://ohiostatepress.org/books/Complete%20PDFs/Nelson%20Mental/08.pdf |title=Link }}</ref><ref>Kenneth Hopper and William Hopper, ''The Puritan Gift: Reclaiming the American Dream Amidst Global Financial Chaos'' (I B Tauris, 2009) [http://www.ibtauris.com/Books/Humanities/History/History%20specific%20events%20%20topics/Social%20%20cultural%20history/The%20Puritan%20Gift%20Reclaiming%20the%20American%20Dream%20Amidst%20Global%20Financial%20Chaos.aspx IB Tauris link] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160826030630/http://www.ibtauris.com/Books/Humanities/History/History%20specific%20events%20%20topics/Social%20%20cultural%20history/The%20Puritan%20Gift%20Reclaiming%20the%20American%20Dream%20Amidst%20Global%20Financial%20Chaos.aspx |date=2016-08-26 }}</ref> In 1916 he established a consulting firm in [[Cleveland]], the Chas. E. Bedaux Company.
[[File:Bedaux consultancy advertising booklet (1928).jpg|thumb|Bedaux consultancy advertising booklet (1928)]]
Early U.S. clients were in the furniture assembly and rubber sectors of [[Grand Rapids]], [[Michigan]].<ref name=Weatherburn /><ref>http://www.historygrandrapids.org/article/4349/f-stuart-foote-brings-bedaux-t</ref> His consultancy's slogan was ''Bedaux Measures Labor'' and its logo incorporated an [[egg timer]] motif.<ref name=Weatherburn />
The Bedaux consultancy was one of the first of its kind and within a decade its success allowed for the creation of a string of consultancy firms across the United States, [[Europe]], and eventually throughout [[Africa]],<ref>Jon Lewis, ''Industrialisation and Trade Union Organisation in South Africa, 1924-55: the Rise and Fall of the South African Trades and Labour Council'' (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1984)</ref> India,<ref>Rajnarayan Chandavarkar, 'Workers' Resistance and the Rationalization of Work in Bombay Between the Wars' in Douglas E. Haynes and Gyan Prakash (eds), ''Contesting Power: Resistance and Everyday Social Relations in India'' (Berkeley and Los Angeles, University of California Press, 1992)</ref><ref>Anthony Cox, ''Empire, Industry and Class: The Imperial Nexus of Jute, 1840-1940'' (London: Routledge, 2013).</ref> Australia and the [[Orient]] administered by the parent company, Bedaux Internationale.<ref name="bedaux">{{cite web| last =Bedaux| title =Charles Bedaux| url =http://www.bedaux.com/com/bedaux/charlesbedaux.php| accessdate =2007-07-10| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20120614224144/http://www.bedaux.com/com/bedaux/charlesbedaux.php| archivedate =2012-06-14| df =}}</ref>
Major Bedaux clients included [[DuPont]],<ref>John C. Rumm, 'Scientific Management and Industrial Engineering at Du Pont' in ''A Mental Revolution: Scientific Management Since Taylor'' (1992). {{cite web|url= https://ohiostatepress.org/books/Complete%20PDFs/Nelson%20Mental/09.pdf |title=Link }}</ref> [[Imperial Chemical Industries]],<ref name="Link"/> [[Anglo-Persian Oil Company|Anglo-Persian Oil Company (later BP)]],<ref>Matthias Kipping, 'Consultancy and Conflicts: Bedaux at Lukens Steel and the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company' ''Entreprises et Histoire'' Vol. 25 (2000), pp.9-25.</ref> [[Fiat]],<ref name=Musso>Stefano Musso, 'Production Methods and Industrial Relations at Fiat (1930- 90)' in Haruhito Shiomi and Kazuo Wada (eds.), ''Fordism Transformed: The Development of Production Methods in the Automobile Industry'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1995). [https://books.google.com/books/about/Fordism_Transformed.html?id=n_DkQmbbg8cC&redir_esc=y Google Books online]</ref> and [[Campbell's]].<ref name="Sidorick">Daniel Sidorick, ''Condensed Capitalism Campbell Soup and the Pursuit of Cheap Production in the Twentieth Century'' (2009)</ref>
==Labor resistance== The Bedaux system was introduced at [[Campbell's]] in 1927, where ''B'' standards were 'the cause of the majority of the shop floor battles between management and labor' for years.<ref name="Sidorick"/> In 1929, the [[Taylor Society]] supported Southern textile workers in their [[strike action|strike]] against the Bedaux System, which textile workers believed was 'even worse than the old "Taylor Stop-Watch System"'.<ref>Milton Nadworny, ''Scientific Management and the Unions: 1900- 1932. A Historical Analysis'' (Cambridge: Harvard University Press, 1955)</ref> There was also a long series of labor disputes in relation to Bedaux and the [[Loyal Legion of Loggers and Lumbermen|Loyal Legion of Loggers and Lumbermen (4L)]] in the U.S. Northwest lumber industry from 1931-5.<ref>Jeremy Egolf, 'Labor Control in Crisis: the 4L and the Bedaux System in the U.S. Northwest Lumber Industry, 1931-1935' (University of British Columbia MA thesis, 1980) {{cite web|url= https://open.library.ubc.ca/cIRcle/collections/ubctheses/831/items/1.0094679 |title=Link }}</ref>
[[File:Bedaux Hell in the 'Daily Worker'.jpg|thumb|A cartoon attacking the Bedaux B in the Daily Worker]]
Bedaux Britain had several labor issues: in 1929, there was a strike over the Bedaux System at the [[Rover Company|Rover]] plant in [[Coventry]].<ref>Laura Lee Downs, 'Industrial Decline, Rationalization and Equal Pay: The Bedaux Strike at Rover Automobile Company' ''Social History'' Vol. 15, No. 1 (1990)</ref> In winter 1931-2, women workers struck over the introduction of the Bedaux System at [[Wolsey (clothing)|Wolsey]] in [[Leicester]].<ref>'[http://www.bbc.co.uk/legacies/work/england/leicester/article_1.shtml 'The Bedaux strike': Oral history study from [[BBC]]]</ref><ref>Selina Todd, ''The People: The Rise and Fall of the Working Class'' (London: John Murray, 2014)</ref> Additionally, in 1934 the introduction of the Bedaux System at [[Richard Johnson and Nephew]] in [[Manchester]] precipitated a strike which lasted for months.<ref name=Littler /><ref>Mick Jenkins, 'Time and Motion Strike: Manchester 1934-7' ''Our History'' Vol. 60 (Autumn 1974)</ref> In this case, the wiredrawers' union took their employers to court over the Bedaux System but eventually lost their case.<ref name=Weatherburn />
One of Bedaux's principal engagements in Italy was at the iconic [[Fiat]] plant in [[Turin]], whose founder [[Giovanni Agnelli]] was also head of the Società Italiana Bedaux.<ref name=Weatherburn /><ref name=Musso /> These management interventions were later made famous by the founder of the [[Italian Communist Party]], [[Antonio Gramsci]], whose ''[[Prison Notebooks]]'' analyzed the ramifications of ''[[Taylorism]]'' at the plant. The Bedaux System also met with resistance at the Pertusola mines in [[Sardinia]].<ref>Maria Stella Rollandi, ʻIl sistema Bedaux nelle miniere sarde della "Pertusola" (1927-1935)' ''Studi Storici'', No. 26, Vol. 1, (1985), pp. 69-106.</ref><ref>http://www.minesofsardinia.com/StoriaMiniereIng.php?IdS=12&IdCSM=9&PHPSESSID=</ref>
==Bedaux Britain Ltd.==
Of Bedaux's business empire, Bedaux Britain was particularly lucrative.<ref name=KreisADNB /><ref name=Littler /><ref name=KreisThesis /> Here, the [[Bedaux Unit]] was so successful that it was copied by industrial firms such as [[Rowntree's]] of [[York]] (a corporate member of the [[Taylor Society]]), [[Mander Brothers]] of [[Wolverhampton]], and influential consultancies including [[Lyndall Urwick|Urwick, Orr & Partners]].<ref name=Weatherburn />
Indeed, Bedaux Britain formed the basis for all four of the 'Big Four' European consultancies in the postwar period: [[Associated Industrial Consultants (AIC)]], [[Lyndall Urwick|Urwick, Orr & Partners (UOP)]], [[Production-Engineering (P-E)]] and [[PA Consulting|PA Consulting (PA)]].<ref>Patricia Tisdall, ''Agents of Change: The Development and Practice of Management Consultancy'' (London: Heinemann, 1982).</ref><ref>Matthias Kipping, 'Consultancies, Institutions and the Diffusion of Taylorism in Britain, Germany and France, 1920s to 1950s', ''Business History'' (1997) [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00076799700000146 PDF from Taylor & Francis online]</ref><ref>Michael Ferguson, ''The Rise of Management Consulting in Britain'' (Aldershot: Ashgate, 2002)</ref>
In focusing on factory floor and office efficiency issues, the 'Big Four' Bedauxist consultancies were successful across Western Europe until the 1960s, when they were largely overtaken by U.S. consultancies such as [[McKinsey & Company]], whose efforts were in higher-value activities such as strategy and restructuring.<ref name=mckenna>'Christopher D. McKenna, ''The World's Newest Profession: Management Consulting in the Twentieth Century'' (Cambridge: CUP, 2010). [http://www.cambridge.org/gb/academic/subjects/history/american-history-after-1945/worlds-newest-profession-management-consulting-twentieth-century Cambridge University Press]</ref>
==The Bedaux Canadian Sub-Arctic Expedition== The [[Bedaux Expedition|Bedaux Canadian Sub-Arctic Expedition]] was the grand title Bedaux gave to the expedition he formed to cross the wilderness of Northern [[British Columbia]], Canada in 1934. Mostly, the expedition was a [[publicity stunt]], but it was also formed to test out the new [[Citroën]] [[half-track]] cars that were being developed by Bedaux's friend [[André Citroën]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Saskatoon Sun |title=Rumours surround legendary Bedaux trek |url=http://www.wdm.ca/wdmbedau.html |accessdate=2007-07-10 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928072236/http://www.wdm.ca/wdmbedau.html |archivedate=2007-09-28 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>http://www.historygrandrapids.org/article/4356/bedaux-canadian-subartic-exped</ref> Key points in the trip were filmed by [[Academy Award]] winning cinematographer from [[Hollywood]], [[Floyd Crosby]], who would later be praised for his work on ''[[High Noon]]''. Also along for the trip were several dozen [[Alberta]] [[cowboy]]s and a large film crew.<ref>Jay Sherwood, ''Bannock and Beans: A Cowboy's Account of the Bedaux Expedition'' (2009) [http://surveyingbc.ca/bann.htm summary]</ref> To map the route of the expedition, the Canadian government sent along two geographers, [[Frank Swannell]] and Ernest Lemarque. The expedition started off at [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]] on 6 July 1934 and their goal was to travel 1500 miles to [[Telegraph Creek, British Columbia]]. Much of the trip would have to be made through regions that were relatively uncharted and had no trails.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bob Dyke |title=Bedaux Expedition |url=http://www.fsj.nlc.bc.ca/nlc/sroe/bob_dyke.htm |accessdate=2007-07-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051214225117/http://www.fsj.nlc.bc.ca/nlc/sroe/bob_dyke.htm |archivedate=December 14, 2005 }}</ref> The party failed to reach their destination and the original movie was never made, but in 1995, [[Canadians|Canadian]] director, George Ungar,<ref>'[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0881089/ George Ungar on [[IMDB]]]</ref> produced a television biography of Bedaux incorporating Crosby's footage of the expedition, ''[[The Champagne Safari]]'' (1995).<ref>'[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0112657/ ''The Champagne Safari'' (1995) on [[IMDB]] entry]</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Vettese |first1=Richard |title=Champagne Safari |url=http://www.historygrandrapids.org/article/4358/champagne-safari |website=History Grand Rapids.org by the Grand Rapids Historical Commission |publisher=Grand Rapids Community Media Center |accessdate=8 August 2018 |location=[[Grand Rapids]], [[Michigan]], US |language=en-us |date=9 April 2013}}</ref> [[File:ChateauCandé-B.jpg|thumb|left|Charles Bedaux hosted the Windsors' wedding in his [[Château de Candé]].]]
==The Duke and Duchess of Windsor== Bedaux purchased the sixteenth-century [[Château de Candé]], in France, and lived there with his American second wife, the former Fern Lombard (1892–1972), a daughter of lawyer James Lombard of Grand Rapids, Michigan.<ref name=KreisADNB /> The couple purchased the château in 1927 and renovated it, completing work in 1930.<ref name="experienceloire.com">http://www.experienceloire.com/chateau-de-cande.htm</ref>
On 3 June 1937, Charles and Fern Bedaux hosted the wedding of [[Wallis, The Duchess of Windsor|Wallis Warfield]] and [[Edward VIII of the United Kingdom|Prince Edward, Duke of Windsor]] at the château.<ref name=KreisADNB /> Bedaux then arranged the couple's honeymoon to the [[Third Reich]], where they publicly met the [[Führer]], [[Adolf Hitler]].<ref name=KreisADNB />
[[File:Charles Bedaux and wife.jpg|thumb|Charles Bedaux and wife]]
[[File:Charles E. Bedaux with Duke and Duchess of Windsor, 1937.jpg|thumb|Charles and Fern Bedaux with the Duke and Duchess of Windsor on their honeymoon en route from Budapest to Paris, summer 1937.]]
==The Duke and Duchess's U.S.A. tour== The next stage of the trip, the United States, was called off due to [[labor union]], press and public outrage at Bedaux's involvement. He was quickly [[demonized]] in the media around the globe. Specifically, the [[Baltimore Federation of Labor]] publicly attacked the 'emissaries of dictatorships or uniformed sentimentalists' and called the [[Bedaux System]] a 'vicious adaptation of the [[Taylor System]]'.<ref name=Weatherburn />
From then on, commentators conceptually linked Bedaux and his ''B'' system with [[fascism]], and Taylor's remaining supporters, particularly those in the [[Taylor Society]], distanced themselves from Bedaux.<ref name=Weatherburn />
The fiasco prompted many employers using the Bedaux System, and those derived from it, to change its terminology to more neutral and administrative language.<ref name=KreisADNB /><ref name=Weatherburn /><ref name="Sidorick"/> This goes some way to explain why historical research into the enduring influence of the Bedaux System and its [[Bedaux Unit]] has been reported as difficult to undertake.<ref name=Weatherburn /><ref>Craig R. Littler, 'The Bureaucratization of the Shop-Floor: the Development of Modern Work Systems' (PhD thesis, London School of Economics, 1980), Vol. 2.</ref>
==Second World War activity== When Paris was occupied by the [[Germans]] during [[World War II]], Bedaux became acquainted with leading Nazi and [[Vichy France|Vichy]] figures. After the fall of France in 1940, he was appointed as an economic advisor to Vichy and the [[Reich]].
Bedaux's wife, Fern, and her sister, Eve Duez (Mme Louis S Duez), were interned briefly in Paris during the war but were soon released through their connections to the German government in France.<ref>"My attention was drawn to a woman who was sitting on the edge of a cot with an ermine wrap around her feet. She was passing around a five-pound box of chocolates to her friends. I learned that she was Mrs. Charles Bedaux, at whose chateau the Duke of Windsor married Mrs. Simpson. Mrs. Bedaux said in a very loud voice that she did not expect to be with us long, and that she was waiting for Otto Abetz, Nazi fifth columnist in France before the war and the new Nazi Ambassador to France, to come and get her and her sister released. Next morning a group of French collaborationists, obviously personages high in treachery, arrived with an important German in uniform. They were very respectful to Mrs. Bedaux, helped her pack her things, and out she swept, while the rest of us were enraged at this exhibition of the power of social and political influence." From '' The House Near Paris: An American Woman's Story of Traffic in Patriots'' by Drue Tartière and M R Werner, Simon & Schuster, 1946, page 105.</ref>
In 1941, Bedaux experimented with a political-economic system of his own invention, ''Equivalism'', in [[Roquefort]], [[Vichy France]]. Recent research has shown that the experiments amounted to tinkering which locals hardly noticed.<ref name=LevantNikitin>Yves Levant & Marc Nikitin, 'Charles Eugène Bedaux (1886–1944): ‘cost killer’ or Utopian Socialist?' ''Accounting, Business & Financial History'' (2009) [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/09585200902969278 Taylor & Francis online]</ref>
Also in 1941, in France, there was a violent coal strike over the [[Bedaux System]] in the Nord and Pas de Calais in May and June.<ref>Richard Vinen, 'The French Coal Industry during the Occupation' ''The Historical Journal'' Vol. 33, No. 1 (1990)</ref>
Bedaux's German connections were not restricted to Occupied France. In October 1941 he was designated by the sabotage branch of the [[Abwehr]] (Abwehr II) to command a covert mission to [[Persia]] ([[Iran]]) to capture the refinery at [[Abadan]] from his former client, the [[Anglo-Persian Oil Company]], and protect it from Allied bombardment prior to a planned German military invasion of [[Iraq]] and Persia.<ref>The sheer scale of such an operation would have been enormous, especially since Bedaux contemplated the “sanding-up” (and subsequent “de-sanding”) of not only the Abadan refinery, but also the [[Mosul]] oilfield, as well as the 483 km of pipeline between them, not to mention other infrastructure in southwestern Persia. The proposal was indeed first regarded by the Abwehr planners as a “fantastic” plan, and it looked as if it would not gain acceptance. However, Bedaux persisted and succeeded in getting the plan submitted to a panel of experts who, after meticulous examination, pronounced it technically feasible. The scheme was ultimately cancelled by the Abwehr for various reasons. Those that concerned Bedaux himself were: (1) his expertise was confined strictly to his 1938 survey of the refinery, and he knew even less about Persia than the Persians knew about him; (2) Bedaux's age, poor health, lack of military training and experience, lack of petroleum-engineering qualifications, and inability to speak either [[Persian language|Persian]] or [[German language|German]] made him a poor choice as commander; (3) Bedaux's inappropriate, grandiose demands, such as being given the full rank of general.</ref> By the end of 1942, however, strategic events (e.g. the [[Second Battle of El Alamein]] and the [[Battle of Stalingrad]]) had rendered the operation unworkable, and Bedaux was dropped by [[Berlin]]. The countersabotage plan then became obsolete,<ref name="o'sullivan">{{cite book|last=O'Sullivan|first=Adrian|authorlink=Adrian O'Sullivan|title=German Covert Initiatives and British Intelligence in Persia (Iran), 1939-1945 ([[Doctor of Literature and Philosophy|DLitt et Phil]] dissertation)|publisher=UNISA|location=Pretoria|year=2013}}</ref> though it looked suspicious when Bedaux was later investigated by the [[FBI]] and [[MI5]].<ref name=Weatherburn/>
Despite Bedaux's cultivation of relationships with various [[Abwehr]] and [[Nazi Party]] officials, declassified [[National Archives and Records Administration]] records indicate that Bedaux did not have dealings with the upper echelons of the Party or with officials of the [[Sicherheitsdienst]] (SS Security Service).<ref name=Weatherburn/><ref name="o'sullivan"/>
==Bedaux's arrest and suicide== On 13 January 1943 Bedaux was in [[Algeria]] allegedly supervising the construction of a [[Germany|German]] [[pipeline transport|pipeline]] when he and his son were arrested by the Americans. He was kept in custody without charge for a year.<ref name=KreisADNB /> Bedaux was eventually flown to the [[US]], and, awaiting charges of [[trading with the enemy]] and [[treason]], committed [[suicide]] using an [[overdose]] of [[barbiturates]] while in [[FBI]] custody in [[Miami, Florida|Miami]], [[Florida]].<ref name=KreisADNB /><ref name=Littler /><ref name="o'sullivan"/> His death featured prominently in the contemporary media,<ref name=NYTimesMystery>'Bedaux Legendary as Mystery Man' ''New York Times'', 20 February 1944 [https://www.nytimes.com/1944/02/20/archives/bedaux-legendary-as-mystery-man-one-of-group-credited-with.html ''New York Times'' online archive]</ref> particularly an influential [[The New Yorker|New Yorker]] biographical trilogy by [[Janet Flanner]].<ref name=KreisADNB /><ref name=Weatherburn /><ref name=Littler /><ref name=mckenna /><ref>[[Brenda Wineapple]], ''Genêt: A Biography of Janet Flanner'' (1992) [http://www.nebraskapress.unl.edu/product/Gen%C3%AAt,672627.aspx University of Nebraska Press]</ref> Here, Flanner attacked the [[Bedaux System]] and [[Bedaux Unit]] as, despite Bedaux's verbose claims to originality, she argued that they did not differ 'much from the old [[Frederick Winslow Taylor]] shop-management system of the nineties'.<ref name=Weatherburn />
==Posthumous reputation== The circumstances of Bedaux's death and his posthumous influence remain subjects of research inquiry.<ref name=Weatherburn /><ref name=Littler /><ref name=mckenna /><ref name="o'sullivan"/><ref name="NYTimesMystery"/><ref>http://historyguide.org/author1.html</ref> Despite his contemporary prominence in the media, and in business and consultancy circles, Bedaux did not feature alongside such figures as [[Frederick Winslow Taylor|F.W. Taylor]], [[Hans Renold]] and [[Charles Samuel Myers|Charles Myers]] in the ''[[Making of Scientific Management]]'' trilogy by [[Lyndall Urwick]] and [[Edward Franz Leopold Brech|E.F.L. Brech]].<ref>Lyndall Urwick and E.F.L. Brech, ''The Making of Scientific Management II: Management in British Industry'' (London: Management Publications Trust, 1949) [https://archive.org/details/makingofscientif029853mbp available at Archive.org]</ref> He was also not present in Urwick's comprehensive management [[prosopography]] ''The Golden Book of Management''.<ref>[[Lyndall Urwick]], ''The Golden Book of Management: A Historical Record of the Life and Work of Seventy Pioneers'' (1956)</ref> It remains controversial as to why.<ref name=Weatherburn /><ref name=KreisThesis /><ref name=mckenna />
It has also been suggested that, in an attempt to restore Bedaux's reputation, the French government awarded Bedaux a posthumous [[Légion d'honneur]] on the grounds that he had actually hampered the Germans and guarded Jewish property.<ref name=Gaston /><ref>{{cite book|last=Sebba|first=Anne|authorlink=Anne Sebba|year=2011|title=That Woman: the Life of Wallis Simpson, Duchess of Windsor|publisher=Weidenfeld & Nicolson|location=London|isbn=978-0-297-85896-6|page=199}}</ref> More recent research has been unable to prove the existence of this award.<ref name=LevantNikitin />
A street in Tours, the Avenue Charles Bedaux, is named after Bedaux.<ref>https://www.google.co.uk/maps/place/Avenue+Charles+Bedaux,+37000+Tours,+France/@47.376769,0.6693022,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x47fcd5e67856f60b:0x89410e1c46d7c3fd!8m2!3d47.376769!4d0.6714909</ref>
[[File:Charles Bedaux (1886-1944) grave.png|thumb|Charles Bedaux (1886-1944) grave]]
The [[Château de Candé]] is open to public visitors and is themed around the Duke and Duchess's 1937 wedding. Many of Bedaux's possessions are on display there.<ref name="experienceloire.com"/><ref>https://www.francetoday.com/travel/travel-features/chateau-de-cande-wedding-wallis-simpson-edward-viii/</ref>
==Bedaux in popular culture== Bedaux's most famous [[depiction]] in interwar culture was as a crackpot inventor in [[Charlie Chaplin]]'s ''[[Modern Times (film)|Modern Times]]'' who presents a 'Beddoes' or 'Billowes' 'Feeding Machine' to Chaplin's employer. The malfunctioning contraption was then demonstrated on a restrained and tormented Chaplin.<ref>Mauro F. Guillén, ''Models of Management: Work, Authority, and Organization in a Comparative Perspective'' (Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press, 1994).</ref>
In addition, the 'Bedaux belt' featured in [[George Orwell]]'s ''[[Inside the Whale]]'', alongside other items and people, such as [[Hitler]] and [[Stalin]], which Orwell saw as indicative of the dark side of the period.<ref name=Weatherburn />
Following his death in 1944, Bedaux features by name in [[Upton Sinclair]]'s 1945 novel [[Dragon Harvest]].<ref>https://books.google.com/books?id=OeQlCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT40&dq=Bedaux+upton+sinclair&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Bedaux%20upton%20sinclair&f=false</ref>
Bedaux also appears as a thwarted [[Business process reengineering|efficiency expert]], Monsieur Bedou of Ratio Ltd., in [[Pierre Boulle]]'s ''Sacrilege in Malaya'' (1951).<ref>http://www.prrb.ca/issues/prrb-issue06.pdf</ref>
==Conspiracy theories== Several [[conspiracy theories]] surround Bedaux's life and death. They usually situate Bedaux as a conduit between the [[Nazi]] and British elites, who facilitated important events in [[World War Two]] such as the [[fall of France]] and the alleged [[murder]] of [[Heinrich Himmler]] by British intelligence operatives.<ref>Martin Allen, ''Hidden Agenda: How the Duke of Windsor Betrayed the Allies'' (London: Macmillan, 2000)</ref><ref>Martin Allen, ''The Hitler/Hess Deception: British Intelligence's Best-Kept Secret of the Second World War'' (London: HarperCollins, 2003)</ref><ref>Martin Allen, ''Himmler's Secret War: the Covert Peace Negotiations of Heinrich Himmler'' (London: Robson, 2005)</ref> These stories stem both from contemporary [[sensationalist]] media stories following Bedaux's well-publicised suicide<ref name=NYTimesMystery /> and in publications which followed the [[FBI]]'s release of the Bedaux files in the early 1980s.<ref>Peter Allen, ''The Crown and the Swastika: Hitler, Hess, and the Duke of Windsor'' (London: Hale, 1983) [https://books.google.com/books/about/The_crown_and_the_swastika.html?id=MZ0gAAAAMAAJ Google Books]</ref><ref>Charles Higham, ''Trading with the Enemy: an Exposé of the Nazi-American Money Plot 1933-1949'' (London: Hale, 1983) [http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/682306.Trading_With_The_Enemy Goodreads]</ref> These claims have been subject to recent investigation.<ref name=Weatherburn /><ref>Ernst Haiger, 'Fiction, Facts, and Forgeries: the “Revelations” of Peter and Martin Allen about the History of the Second World War' ''Journal of Intelligence History'' Vol. 6 (2006) [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/16161262.2006.10555127 ''Journal of Intelligence History'']</ref><ref>http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/r/C16525</ref>
Between 2005 and 2008 this issue was compounded by the discovery that key elements of Martin Allen's ''Hidden Agenda'' trilogy were based on twenty-nine forgeries located in the [[UK National Archives]].<ref>Ben Fenton, 'Lies And Secrets' ''Financial Times'', 3 May 2008 [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/f3a43fbc-18ab-11dd-8c92-0000779fd2ac.html?ft_site=falcon&desktop=true#axzz4DfPdTiIX ''Financial Times'' online]</ref><ref>'The 29 Fakes Behind a Rewriting of History' ''The Guardian'', 5 May 2008 [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2008/may/05/nationalarchives.secondworldwar ''The Guardian'' online]</ref><ref>'Forgeries revealed in the National Archives' ''The Sunday Times'', 4 May 2008 [http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/news/uk_news/article90536.ece ''The Sunday Times'' online]</ref> These forged papers explicitly implicated Bedaux high in the elite echelons of the [[Third Reich]]. As part of the police investigation into the case, Allen denied knowledge of the forgeries and 'suggested he was the victim of a conspiracy'.<ref>Ben Fenton, 'Himmler Forgeries in National Archives Case will Stay Unsolved' ''Financial Times'' 3 May 2008 [http://wayback.vefsafn.is/wayback/20100309134935/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/371bb7fe-18aa-11dd-8c92-0000779fd2ac.html ''Financial Times'' online]</ref>

religion = | denomination = <!-- Denomination should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> }} '''Charles Okpaleke''' (born March 14, 1983), popularly known as Charles, is a Nigerian health economist, Nightlife tycoon, Nollywood movie producer and businessman. He was born in Onitsha and raised in Lagos, Nigeria, where he studied in his earlier years. Okpaleke worked as a consultant health economist for various governmental and non-governmental organisations including the United Nations and Family Healthcare International before co-founding the Play Entertainment Network in 2008, alongside his brothers Elvis and Jeffrey Okpaleke.
==Early life and career==
Charles Okpaleke was born in Onitsha in Anambra State, [[Nigeria]] to a family of four that would later grow to become a family of eight. His father, Late Julian Chukwuemeka Okpaleke was a retired Assistant Inspector General of Police in the [[Nigeria Police Force]] prior to his death and his mother; Florence Ngozi Okpaleke, remains a legal practitioner in [[Lagos]] Nigeria.
Okpaleke attended [[King's College, Lagos|Kings College]] in Lagos where he graduated in 1999. He then proceeded to the University of Nigeria, Enugu Campus where he studied Medical Laboratory Science until 2005 when he obtained his Bachelor of Sciences degree. Between 2005 and 2006, Okpaleke landed a Housemanship Programme with the State House Clinic, [[Aso Villa|Aso Rock]], Abuja where he worked as a Medical Laboratory Scientist.
Convinced that his career path would be one in health economics, Okpaleke relocated temporarily to Birmingham, United Kingdom in 2007 to pursue a master's degree in Health Economics and Health Policy. He obtained his MSc in 2007 from the [[University of Birmingham Medical School|University of Birmingham]], United Kingdom and relocated back home to [[Nigeria]] shortly after to focus fully on his chosen career. Upon relocation, Okpaleke was offered a role in Health Economics with Family Healthcare International (FHI) on the Global HIV/AIDS Initiative Nigeria (GHAIN) Project in partnership with the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) and the United States President’s Emergency Plan For AIDS Relief (PEPFAR). He worked on the GHAIN project from 2007 up until 2008 when he decided to include entrepreneurship to his portfolio by cofounding Play Sports Bar<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2016/06/okpaleke-brothers-berth-play-network/|title=Okpaleke Brothers berth ‘Play Network’ - Vanguard News|date=2016-06-18|work=Vanguard News|access-date=2017-06-14|language=en-US}}</ref> and Grill with his brothers.
Upon cofounding Play Sports Bar and Grill, Okpaleke decided to continue as a full-time health economist and full-time entrepreneur. This decision led him to join his alma mater, the [[University of Nigeria, Nsukka|University of Nigeria]], Enugu Campus, as a post graduate lecturer in the faculty of Health Sciences and Technology. Okpaleke continued as a lecturer from 2009 up until 2011.
== Business career == The Play Entertainment Network<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://luxuryreporter.ng/2016/08/the-okpaleke-brothers-luxury-personified/|title=The Okpaleke Brothers Luxury Personified {{!}} WELCOME TO LUXURY REPORTERS|last=LuxuryReporter|website=luxuryreporter.ng|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-14}}</ref> originally began as a Sports Bar in the heart of Wuse in Abuja, Nigeria in the year 2008. The Play Sports Bar enjoyed tremendous growth and popularity amongst the Abuja elite and with this growth came remarkable expansion that necessitated the birth of the Play Entertainment Network. The Play Entertainment Network now serves as a parent company to various businesses and elite nightlife destinations including Play Network Nigeria- a multidisciplinary networking hub for professionals and entrepreneurs, Play Lounge Abuja, Play Lounge Jos, The Underground Lounge Lagos, BLD by Play Restaurant Lagos, Shop and Play Abuja and Play Apparel among others.
In 2015, Okpaleke and his partners’ secured intellectual property rights for the remake of historic Nigerian movie ‘Living in Bondage’,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://authorityngr.com/2015/10/Charles-Okpaleke-acquires--Living-in-Bondage-remaking-rights.html/|title=Charles Okpaleke acquires 'Living in Bondage' remaking rights|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> once again expanding his portfolio and introducing him into the Nigerian Movie Industry, Nollywood.
== Brand affiliations ==
In 2017, Okpaleke concluded an endorsement deal with premium energy drink company, Cintron, as a Brand Ambassador in Nigeria. He was also appointed Brand Influencer for the Remy Martin global ‘One Life’ campaign in 2016.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://thenet.ng/2016/02/shina-peller-vj-adams-charles-okpaleke-the-new-brand-influencers-for-remy-martin-onelifelivethem-campaign/|title=Shina Peller, VJ Adams & Charles Okpaleke – The new brand influencers for Rémy Martin® #OneLifeLiveThem campaign - Nigerian Entertainment Today - Nigeria's Top Website for News, Gossip, Comedy, Videos, Blogs, Events, Weddings, Nollywood, Celebs, Scoop and Games|date=2016-02-16|work=Nigerian Entertainment Today - Nigeria's Top Website for News, Gossip, Comedy, Videos, Blogs, Events, Weddings, Nollywood, Celebs, Scoop and Games|access-date=2017-06-14|language=en-GB}}</ref>
== Personal life == === Family === Okpaleke married Ogochukwu Adimorah<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bellanaija.com/2013/09/bn-spectacular-weddings-ogochukwu-adimorah-charles-okpaleke/|title=BN Spectacular Weddings: Ogochukwu Adimorah & Charles Okpaleke - BellaNaija|website=www.bellanaija.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-14}}</ref> in 2013 in a white ceremony at the Church of Assumption Catholic Church in Asokoro, Abuja. Together, they have two children, a set of twins.
== Philanthropy and memberships ==
In 2015, Okpaleke spearheaded an empowerment initiative, which he tagged ‘Be a boss in 50 seconds’.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://dayoadetiloye.com/millionairebossin15seconds-win-1-million-naira-for-your-legit-hustle-from-charles-okpaleke/|title=#MillionaireBossin15seconds – Win 1 Million Naira for your Legit Hustle from Charles Okpaleke|date=2015-10-06|work=Youth Entrepreneurship|access-date=2017-06-14|language=en-US}}</ref> This initiative targets young prospective entrepreneurs that require external funding, giving them an opportunity to pitch their business ideas to a team of judges selected by Okpaleke from a host of relevant industries. At the end of each ‘Be a Boss’ cycle, the Play Entertainment Network funds the most reasonable business idea with no return on investment expected.
In 2016, Okpaleke was appointed the Chairman of the Rotary Club of Abuja Federal, a post he held for a one-year cycle.
As far as political memberships and association are concerned, Okpaleke continues to refer to himself as a non-partisan individual, holding no strong political memberships or affiliations. To further establish his preference, Okpaleke created a youth forum in 2015 under the Play Network called P.L.A.Y. (Political Leadership Among Youths). From its inception till date, the P.L.A.Y. forum has encouraged youth participation in Nigerian politics regardless of sex, tribe, religion or political affiliation.
