{{refimprove|date=April 2015}} A '''''Stichting''''' (foundation) is a Dutch legal entity with [[limited liability]], but no members or share capital, that exists for a specific purpose.<ref>http://www.step.org/dutch-foundation</ref> This form of entity makes it possible to separate functions of ownership and control. Its use has been pioneered successfully in recent years as a 'poison pill' style defence tactic in hostile takeover situations by Scott V Simpson, one of Europe's leading mergers and acquisitions lawyers.<ref>The Wall Street Journal 'Going Dutch Has New Meaning In Corporate Takeover Battles' May 22, 2006</ref>
==Formation== A Stichting is a legal person created through a legal act. This act is usually either a notarised deed (or a will) that contains the articles of the foundation which must include the first appointed board. No government authority is involved in the creation or authorization of a foundation. It acquires full legal capacity through its sole creation. A foundation has no members and its purpose must be stated in its articles, using capital dedicated to such goal. The foundations are defined in the Dutch Civil Code ([[Burgerlijk Wetboek]]), Boek 2 Art 285-304. It is not necessary in the Netherlands that a foundation serves a purpose of general interest, but its official goal cannot include making payments to anybody, except for charitable causes. A foundation is governed and represented by a board that is responsible for the foundation's administration. The board does not have a requirement for specific number of members.
Art. 2:289 of the Civil Code establishes that all foundations must be registered in the Register of Commerce or "Kamer van Koophandel". Commercial activities are allowed if they are within the purpose of the foundation and are taxed. Board members can be held liable for the foundation, civilly as well as criminally.
The Dutch Tax Service can declare an institution to be an "institution for general benefit" ([[algemeen nut beogende instelling|ANBI]]), with tax benefits. Often, but not necessarily, this is a foundation. Conversely, not every foundation qualifies.
==Examples==
===Charitable organizations=== *[[Cornelis Kruseman Stichting]] – purpose: bring the work of painter [[Cornelis Kruseman]] (1797–1857) to the attention of the public. *[[Museumkaart|Stichting Museumjaarkaart]] – purpose: promote visits to Dutch museums. *[[Nederlandse Omroep Stichting]] – purpose: make news and sports programmes for the three Dutch public television channels and the Dutch public radio services. *[[P2P Foundation]] that promotes peer to peer networking and action research. *[[FERN|Stichting FERN]] – purpose: promote greater environmental and social justice, focusing on forests and forest peoples’ rights. *[[Stichting INGKA Foundation]] – purpose: promote and support innovation in the field of architectural and interior design. *[[Stichting Max Havelaar]] – purpose: the Dutch member of Fairtrade International. *[[Stichting Pensioenfonds ABP]] – pension fund for the government and educational sectors. *[[Stichting Pensioenfonds Zorg en Welzijn]] – pension fund for the healthcare and social work sectors. *[[Wiardi Beckman Stichting]] – purpose: a think tank linked to the Labour Party ([[Labour Party (Netherlands)|PvdA]]). *[[Mars One]] – purpose: establish a permanent human colony on Mars. *[[MINIX 3]] – Stichting MINIX Research Foundation - purpose: Support and develop Minix3 Operating System.
===Takeover defense=== Stichting are used as a type of [[poison pill]] (takeover defense mechanism) for publicly traded companies. In one case, the Dutch-incorporated pharmaceutical company [[Mylan]] established a stichting for the purpose of "safeguarding Mylan’s strategy, mission and independence" and gave the stichting the right to veto any proposed [[hostile takeover]] of Mylan.<ref name="wsj">{{cite news|last1=Raice|first1=Shayndi|title=The Rise of the ‘Stichting,’ an Obscure Takeover Defense|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-rise-of-the-stichting-an-obscure-takeover-defense-1429716204|accessdate=28 July 2015|work=Wall Street Journal|date=22 April 2015}}</ref> The stichting was activated in July 2015 to block a planned takeover by [[Teva Pharmaceutical Industries]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Raice|first1=Shayndi|title=Mylan’s Leverage to Resist Teva Deal Reveals Shift in Rules|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/mylans-leverage-to-resist-teva-deal-reveals-shift-in-rules-1438029585?tesla=y|accessdate=28 July 2015|work=Wall Street Journal|date=27 July 2015}}</ref>
===Finance and investment=== Stichting are used by institutional investors, such as banks and wealthy individuals, as a means of controlling assets while not having legal ownership or consolidating the assets on their financial statements. The properties of stichting can be used to avoid [[inheritance tax]], [[trade sanctions]] and [[expropriation]]. In one case, the Libyan-based oil company [[Oilinvest]] used a stichting structure to avoid sanctions on Libya and ensure its continued operation following the overthrow of [[Muammar Gaddafi]]; in another case, the Russian oil company [[Yukos]] used a stichting structure in an attempt to shield its assets from tax claims by the Russian government.<ref name="wsj" />
==Netherlands Antilles== Foundation legislation was last reformed in 1998, giving rise to the [[Netherlands Antilles]] Private Foundation (Stichting Particulier Fonds).

'''''The Empire of Business''''' is a collection of essays written by [[Scottish-American]] industrialist [[Andrew Carnegie]] which were published in book form in 1902.
The book shares his shrewd outlook on the economic situation in America at the turn of the 20th century; Carnegie discusses the rewards of hard work, integrity, frugality and other prudent qualities such as the "bugaboo of trusts" that he believes every person should possess if they wish to achieve success in their lifetime. Topics include the state of the oil and steel industries within the United States and the best uses of tariffs.
The essays that form the book have been gathered from a number of well received publications from the era, these include the ''[[New York Evening Post]]'', the ''[[New York Journal]]'' and ''[[Macmillan's Magazine]]''. ''The Empire of Business'' provides the reader with an insight into one of history’s most notable entrepreneurs. Andrew Carnegie is also often described as the most prominent philanthropist in history.

{{Refimprove|date=October 2016}} '''Total shareholder return''' ('''TSR''') (or simply '''total return''') is a [[Measurement|measure]] of the performance of different companies' [[stocks]] and [[shares]] over time. It combines [[share price]] appreciation and [[dividends]] paid to show the total return to the [[shareholder]] expressed as an annualized percentage. It is calculated by the growth in capital from purchasing a share in the company assuming that the dividends are [[reinvested]] each time they are paid. This growth is expressed as a percentage as the [[compound annual growth rate]].
The main benefit of TSR is that it allows the performance of shares to be compared even though some of the shares may have a high growth and low dividends and others may have low growth and high dividends.
Most [[Stock market index|stock market indices]] only use the growth of the prices of the companies making up the index. However, when they use TSR for the companies it is called a [[total return index]] or accumulation index. For example, corresponding to the [[S&P 500]] index calculated by [[Standard and Poor's]], there is the S&P 500 TR index.
In the technology sector, a study has found that regardless of a company's size, the more diverse the portfolio, the more difficult it is to generate high TSR.<ref>{{cite web|last1=DiGrande|first1=Sebastian|last2=Zajac|first2=Jason|last3=Nolan|first3=Tim|last4=Borno|first4=Ruba|title=Break Up of Shake Up: Get Ready for the Technology Industry Revolution|url=https://www.transactionadvisors.com/insights/break-or-shake-get-ready-technology-industry-revolution|publisher=Transaction Advisors|ISSN=2329-9134}}</ref>
In practice TSR is difficult to calculate since it involves knowing the price of the shares at the time the dividends are paid. However, as an approximation over one year it can be calculated as follows with:
<math>Price_{begin}</math> = share price at beginning of year,
<math>Price_{end}</math> = share price at end of year,
''Dividends'' = dividends paid over year and
''TSR'' = total shareholder return, TSR is computed as
<math> TSR={(Price_{end} - Price_{begin} + Dividends)}/{Price_{begin}}</math>

'''Wipro Limited''' is an India-based information technology, consulting and business process services company headquartered in [[Bengaluru, India]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wipro.com/en-IN/about-us/|title=About Wipro|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>.
In 2013, Wipro demerged its non-IT businesses into separate companies.<ref name="thehindubusinessline"/> {{TOC limit}}
==History==
===Early formative years=== The company was incorporated on 29 December 1945 in Amalner, Maharashtra by Mohamed Premji as "Western India Vegetable Products Limited", later abbreviated to "Wipro". It was initially set up as a manufacturer of vegetable and [[cooking oil#Refinement|refined oils]] in [[Amalner]], Maharashtra, India under the [[trade name]]<nowiki/>s of Kisan, Sunflower, and Camel.<ref name=NPHistory/><ref name="moneycontrol-wipro-history"/><ref name="companyhistory">{{cite web|url=http://www.wipro.com/about-Wipro/|title="About Wipro"|website=wipro.com|accessdate=22 September 2017}}</ref>
In 1966, after Mohamed Premji's death, his son [[Azim Premji]] returned home from [[Stanford University]] and took over Wipro as its [[chairman]] at the age of 21.<ref name="Billionaire Profile: Azim Premji"/><ref name="Financial Express"/>
During the 1970s and 1980s, the company shifted its focus to new business opportunities in the IT and computing industry, which was at a nascent stage in India at the time. On 7 June 1977, the name of the company changed from Western India Vegetable Products Limited, to Wipro Products Limited.<ref name="moneycontrol-wipro-history"/>
The year 1980 marked the arrival of Wipro in the IT domain. In 1982, the name was changed from Wipro Products Limited to Wipro Limited.<ref name="Company profile for Wipro"/> Meanwhile, Wipro continued to expand in the consumer products domain with the launch of "Ralak" a [[Tulsi]] based family soap and "Wipro Jasmine", a toilet soap. In 1988 Premji took a loan of 1 million dollars from Sonkar and Sons to set up the project. Later the entire loan amount was waived.<ref name="moneycontrol-wipro-history"/>
===1986–1992=== In 1988, Wipro diversified its product line into heavy-duty industrial cylinders and mobile hydraulic cylinders.<ref name="moneycontrol-wipro-history"/> A joint venture company with the United States' [[General Electric]] in the name of Wipro GE Medical Systems Pvt. Ltd. was set up in 1989 for the manufacture, sales, and service of diagnostic and imaging products.<ref name="economictimes-wipro-history"/> Later, in 1991, tipping systems and Eaton hydraulic products were launched. The Wipro Fluid Power division, in 1992, developed expertise to offer standard hydraulic cylinders for construction equipment and truck tipping systems. The market saw the launch of the "Santoor" talcum powder and "Wipro Baby Soft" range of baby toiletries in 1990.<ref name="economictimes-wipro-history"/>
===1994–2000=== In 1995, Wipro set up an overseas design centre, Odyssey 21, for undertaking projects and product developments in advanced technologies for overseas clients. Wipro Infotech and Wipro Systems were amalgamated with Wipro in April that year.<ref name="economictimes-wipro-history"/> Five of Wipro's manufacturing and development facilities secured the ISO 9001 certification during 1994–95. In 1999, Wipro acquired Wipro Acer.<ref name="Corporate Round-up"/> Wipro became a more profitable, diversified corporation with new products such as the Wipro SuperGenius personal computers (PCs). In 1999, the product was the one Indian PC range to obtain US-based National Software Testing Laboratory ([[National Software Testing Laboratories|NSTL]]) certification for the Year 2000 ([[Y2K]]) compliance in hardware for all models.<ref name="In brief"/>
Wipro Limited joined with [[KPN]] (Royal Dutch telecom) to form a [[joint venture]] company "Wipro Net Limited" to provide internet services in India.<ref name="Financial Express"/> In 2000 Wipro launched Wipro OSS Smart and Wipro WAP Smart.<ref name="Wipro releases WAP solutions"/> In the same year, Wipro got listed on [[New York Stock Exchange]]<ref name="Wipro lists on NYSE with marginal premium"/> and it Premji approached [[KPMG]] to form a mega-outsourcing joint venture between the two organizations.{{cn|date=September 2018}}
===2001–2010=== In February 2002, Wipro became the first [[software]] technology and services company in India to be [[ISO 14001]] certified.<ref name="Wipro Tech gets ISO 14001"/> Wipro Consumer Care and Lighting Group entered the market of [[compact fluorescent lamp]]<nowiki/>s, with the launch of a range of CFL, under the brand name of Wipro Smartlite.<ref name="Wipro lighting launches new range"/> As the company grew, a study revealed that Wipro was the fastest wealth creator for 5 years (1997–2002).<ref name="Wipro Is Fastest Wealth Creator For 5 Years: Study"/><ref name="Wipro is biggest wealth creator during 1998-2003: Study"/> It set up a wholly owned subsidiary company (Wipro Consumer Care Limited) to manufacture consumer care and lighting products.<ref name="Wipro to set up consumer care unit in Himachal"/> In 2004 Wipro joined the billion dollar club.<ref name="Wipro joins billion dollar club, announces 2:1 bonus shares"/> It also partnered with [[Intel]] for i-shiksha.<ref name="Wipro and Intel launch 'I-Shiksha' solution"/><ref name="Wipro, Intel Join Forces to Launch i-shiksha"/> In 2006 Wipro acquired cMango Inc., a US-based technology infrastructure Consulting firm<ref name="thehindubusinessline2006"/><ref name="Wipro bags US consulting co cMango"/> Enabler, and a Europe-based retail solutions provider.<ref name="India's Wipro acquires Enabler"/> In 2007, Wipro signed a large deal with Lockheed Martin.<ref name="Lockheed Martin, Wipro To Light Ambar Jyoti in India"/><ref name="Wipro-Lockheed-Martin"/> It also agreed to acquire Oki Techno Centre Singapore Pte Ltd (OTCS)<ref name="Wipro-Lockheed-Martin"/><ref name="Wipro to Acquire Oki's Wireless Chip Design Arm"/> and signed an R&D partnership contract with Nokia Siemens Networks in Germany.<ref name="Wipro to manage R&D for Nokia Siemens"/><ref name="Wipro to buy Nokia Siemens R&D unit in Berlin"/>
In 2008 Wipro’s entered the clean energy business with Wipro Eco Energy.<ref name="The Inside Story of Azim Premji's Next Billion Dollar Plan"/><ref name="Stable, yet supple"/>
===2011-2018=== In April 2011, Wipro signed an agreement with [[Science Applications International Corporation]] (SAIC) for the acquisition of their global oil and gas information technology practice.<ref name="indiatimes"/><ref name="reuters"/> In 2012 Wipro employed more than 70,000 [[H-1B visa]] professional temporary workers in the United States.<ref name="Top 10 Employers"/>
In 2012 Wipro acquired Australian Trade Promotions Management firm Promax Applications Group (PAG) for $35 million.<ref name="Wipro to acquire Australia's Promax Applications Group for Rs 192 crore"/><ref name="business-standard"/> Also, in that year, Wipro Ltd. demerged its consumer care, lighting, furniture, infrastructure engineering (hydraulics and water and medical diagnostic business) into a separate company to be named 'Wipro Enterprises Ltd'.<ref name="Wipro hives off non-IT business into separate company"/><ref name="Wipro's Scheme of Arrangement for Demerger Effective from March 31, 2013"/><ref name="Wipro demerger scheme comes into effect"/> Prior to demerger, these companies together contributed about 10% of the revenues of Wipro Limited.<ref name="Wipro to demerge non-IT businesses"/><ref name="Azim Premji says son Rishad will never be CEO of Wipro"/>
In 2014, Wipro signed a 10-year $1.2 billion contract with [[ATCO]], a Canadian Energy & Utilities corporation based in [[Calgary, Alberta]]. This was the largest deal in Wipro's history.<ref name = "Canada Progress"/> In October 2016, Wipro announced that it was buying [[Appirio]], an [[Indianapolis]]-based cloud services company for $500 million.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wipro.com/newsroom/press-releases/Wipro-to-acquire-Appirio-A-global-cloud-services-company/|title=Wipro to acquire Appirio, A Global Cloud Services Company|website=www.wipro.com|access-date=2016-12-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/10/20/indias-wipro-buys-cloud-services-consultancy-appirio-for-500m/|title=India’s Wipro buys cloud consultancy and work marketplace Appirio for $500M|last=Lunden|first=Ingrid|website=TechCrunch|access-date=2016-12-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2016/10/20/wipro-buys-appirio/|title=Why IT Services Giant Wipro Is Snapping Up Appirio for $500 Million.|last=FORTUNE|website=Fortune|access-date=2016-12-26}}</ref> In 2017, the company expanded its operations in London.<ref>{{Citation | publication-date = December 6, 2017 | title =Wipro to expand operations in London, to set up 3rd office | newspaper =[[The Economic Times]] | url =https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/tech/ites/wipro-to-expand-operations-in-london-to-set-up-3rd-office/articleshow/61951957.cms | accessdate = }}</ref>
In 2017, Wipro Limited won a five-year IT infrastructure and applications managed services engagement with Grameenphone (GP), a leading telecom operator in Bangladesh and announced it would set up a new delivery centre there.[https://www.wipro.com/newsroom/press-releases/2017/wipro-wins-managed-services-engagement-with-grameenphone/]
In 2018, the company began building software to help with the [[General Data Protection Regulation]] (GDPR) in Europe.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/tech/ites/indian-it-like-wipro-cognizant-set-to-cash-in-on-eus-privacy-regime/articleshow/64088184.cms|title=Indian IT like Wipro, Cognizant set to cash in on EU's privacy regime|last=Christopher|first=Nilesh|date=2018-05-09|work=The Economic Times|access-date=2018-05-30|last2=Pramanik|first2=Ayan}}</ref> In March 2018, Wipro said it would be buying a third of Denim Group.<ref>{{Citation | last =Mendonca | first =Jochelle | publication-date = March 1, 2018 | title =Wipro to buy a third of US application security company for $8.8 million | newspaper =[[The Economic Times]] | url =https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/tech/ites/wipro-to-buy-a-third-of-us-application-security-company-for-8-8-million/articleshow/63126667.cms | accessdate = }}</ref> In April 2018, the company sold its stake in the airport IT services company JV.<ref>{{Citation | publication-date = April 6, 2018 | title =Wipro sells 63% stake in airport IT services JV | newspaper =[[The Economic Times]] | url =https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/tech/ites/wipro-sells-63-stake-in-airport-it-services-jv/articleshow/63647810.cms | accessdate = }}</ref>
In August 2018, WiPro paid US $75m to National Grid US as a settlement for a botched SAP implementation that a 2014 audit estimated could cost the company US $1 billion. Wipro had been hired as systems integrator in 2010, but errors in the rollout, intended to replace an Oracle system, caused serious losses and reputational damage.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2018/08/06/botched_sap_implementation_national_grid_wipro_settlement_75m/|title=Wipro hands $75m to National Grid US after botched SAP upgrade|last=Hill|first=Rebecca|date=6 August 2018|work=[[The Register]]|access-date=6 September 2018}}</ref>
To compete with [[Hindustan Unilever]] and [[Procter & Gamble]], in May 2018 Wipro Consumer Care and Lighting announced it would increase Indian distribution of its acquired personal care brands Enchanteur and [[Yardley of London|Yardley]]. Other recent acquisitions included Unza Holdings, LD Waxson, and [[Zhongshan]].<ref name="A">{{Citation | last =Bhushan | first =Ratna | publication-date = May 3, 2018 | title =Wipro consumer to push global brands in India | newspaper =[[The Economic Times]] | url =https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/tech/ites/wipro-consumer-to-push-global-brands-in-india/articleshow/64009091.cms }}</ref> On May 3, 2018, it was announced that Wipro was opening manufacturing locations in [[Andhra Pradesh]] and [[Guangzhou]].<ref>{{Citation | publication-date = May 3, 2018 | title =BRIEF-Wipro Consumer Care & Lighting Plans To Add Manufacturing Locations In Andhra Pradesh, Guangzhou | newspaper =[[Reuters]] | url =https://www.reuters.com/article/brief-wipro-consumer-care-lighting-plans/brief-wipro-consumer-care-lighting-plans-to-add-manufacturing-locations-in-andhra-pradesh-guangzhou-idUSFWN1SA05J | accessdate = }}</ref> On May 4, 2018, it was reported that Wipro's stock value had been decreasing.<ref name="B">{{Citation | publication-date = May 4, 2018 | title =Wipro hits 10-month low; chart signals further downside | newspaper =[[The Hindu Business Line]] and [[Reuters]] | url =https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/markets/stock-markets/wipro-hits-10-month-low-chart-signals-further-downside/article23769190.ece }}</ref> The day earlier, press had said that [[HCL Technologies|HCL]] would likely unseat Wipro that quarter as the third largest Indian IT company, after TCS and [[Infosys]].<ref name="D">{{Citation | last =Phadnis | first =Shilpa | publication-date = May 3, 2018 | title =HCL likely to unseat Wipro as No. 3 IT player this quarter | newspaper =[[The Times of India]] | url =https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/hcl-likely-to-unseat-wipro-as-no-3-it-player-this-quarter/articleshow/64010084.cms }}</ref>
==Subsidiaries==
===Western India Products Limited=== Wipro Limited is a global provider of comprehensive IT solutions and services, including Systems Integration, Consulting, Information Systems outsourcing, IT-enabled services, R&D services.<ref name="Company Profile for Wipro" />
Wipro entered into the technology business in 1981 and has over 160,000 employees and clients across 54 countries.<ref name="Wipro launches iPhone app" /> IT revenues were at $7.1 billion for the year ended 31 March 2015, with a repeat business ratio of over 95%.<ref name="Results for the quarter and year ended March 31, 2013 under IFRS" /><ref name="Industry, Materials and Utilities" />
===Wipro Consumer Care & Lighting=== Wipro Consumer Care and Lighting (WCCLG), a business unit of Wipro Limited operates in the FMCG segment dealing in consumable commodities. Established in 1945, its first product was vegetable oil, later sold under the brand name "Sunflower Vanaspati". It sells personal care products, such as Wipro Baby Soft and Wipro Safewash, toilet soaps Santoor and Chandrika as well as [[Yardley of London|Yardley]].<ref name="Wipro Consumer Care & Lighting to launch Glucose tablets"/> It sells lighting products, including Smartlite CFL,<ref name="Wipro sees high demand for CFL bulbs"/> LED, and emergency lights.<ref name="Company Overview of Wipro Consumer Care and Lighting Ltd."/>
Through product sales and acquisitions, Wipro Consumer Care and Lighting has grown steadily in the FMCG segment.<ref name="Wipro's Santoor is largest soap brand in South India"/><ref name="financialexpress"/><ref name="Yardley's proof of Wipro's FMCG focus"/>
===Wipro Infrastructure Engineering=== Wipro Infrastructure Engineering is the hydraulics business division of Wipro Limited and has been in the business of manufacturing hydraulic cylinders, truck cylinders, and their components and solutions since 1976. This division delivers hydraulic cylinders to international OEMs and represents the Kawasaki, Sun Hydraulics<ref name="Company History — Wipro Ltd"/> and Teijin Seiki range of hydraulic products in India.<ref name="Wipro, Kawasaki in talks for hydraulic oil pumps"/> It has entered into partnerships Kawasaki<ref name="Wipro, Kawasaki enter into a joint venture"/><ref name="Wipro Infrastructure Engineering to set up Rs 50 cr plant in Bangalore"/> and aerospace giant EADS.<ref name="Wipro Infrastructure Engineering ties up with EADS arm"/> In 2010 Wipro Infrastructure Engineering was the second largest independent manufacturer of hydraulic cylinders in the world.<ref name="Pumping up the world"/>
===Wipro GE Medical Systems=== Wipro GE Medical Systems Limited is Wipro’s joint venture with GE Healthcare South Asia. It is engaged in the research and development of advanced solutions to cater to patient and customer needs in healthcare. This partnership, which began in 1990,<ref name="Wipro GE to consolidate healthcare biz"/> today includes gadgets and equipment for diagnostics, healthcare IT solutions and services to help healthcare professionals combat cancer, heart disease, and other ailments. There is complete adherence to [[Six Sigma]] quality standards in all products.<ref name="About Wipro GE Healthcare"/><ref name="Six Sigma has worked wonders for Wipro GE"/><ref name="Six Sigma has worked wonders for Wipro GE1"/>
==Sustainability== Wipro has been ranked 1st in the 2010 Asian Sustainability Rating (ASR) of Indian companies<ref name="Wipro continues to lead in sustainability disclosures"/> and is a member of the [[NASDAQ]] Global Sustainability Index<ref name="Nasdaq-100 includes Wipro in Global Sustainability Index"/> as well as the [[Dow Jones Sustainability Index]].<ref name="Wipro Named Among World's Most Ethical Companies"/>
In November 2012 ''Guide to Greener Electronics'', [[Greenpeace]] ranked Wipro first with a score of 7.1/10.<ref name="greenpeace"/>

'''YoungGuns International Award''' (also referenced as '''YoungGuns Award''' and '''YGAward''') is an annual global award show for young and emerging creative talent in the advertising and communication industry. The award recognizes the best young commercial practitioners and students across the fields of [[advertising]], [[communication design]], digital creative, [[advertising media]] and [[public relations]] from around the world. Entrants into the award must be aged 30 or under.
Entrants for the award compete for gold, silver and bronze awards across 8 divisions and 40 categories.<ref name=bnt_1 /> Every year, two ultimate winners will be determined and named YoungGun of the Year and YoungGun Student of the Year.
== History == Kristian Barnes, Jason Williams, and Michael Kean (CEO of market-leading global creative recruitment firm FBI Recruitment) founded the YoungGuns Award in 2001 from [[Sydney, Australia]] with the goal of recognizing and promoting upcoming talent rather than rewarding years of experience. They noted that the reason for starting the award was their frustration that major awards at the time were typically won by well established individuals within the industry.<ref name="bnt_1">[http://www.bandt.com.au/news/aussie-young-guns-take-on-the-world "Aussie Young Guns Take on the World"], BNT, 2001.</ref>
== Call for entry == YoungGuns was the first international award to produce an advertising campaign for its call of entries. The campaigns are renowned for being controversial. Most notable include "Peak Early" which focused on child prodigies<ref name="creative1">[http://creativity-online.com/news/young-guns-encourages-creatives-to-peak-early/35509 "Young Guns Encourages Creatives to 'Peak Early'"], Creativity Online 2002</ref> and "Quit in Style" which allowed anyone to upload content such as videos and feedback to demonstrate how they would quit their jobs.<ref name="campbrief">[http://www.campaignbrief.com/2008/08/young-guns-quit-in-style-with.html "Young Guns Quit In Style With DROGA5"], Campaign Brief, 2008.</ref> Despite the controversy the yearly campaigns have proven to be quite appealing to the creative industry. Some campaigns have managed to receive recognition in other creative awards such as the New Zealand Grande Axis<ref name="caanz">[http://www.caanz.co.nz/ma_awards.php?ssearch=ssearch&pid=18&sub=0&nd=&simple_agency=&simple_client=Young+Guns&ssearch=ssearch&submitBtn.x=55&submitBtn.y=22&submitBtn=searching CAANZ Award Winner Listings: Young Guns]</ref> and [[Cannes Lions International Advertising Festival]].
The call for entries campaigns are usually created by selective advertising agencies or creative collaborations from all around the world. Some of the past Call for Entry campaign creators included [[Droga5]], The Glue Society, [[TAXI (advertising agency)|Taxi]], [[Crispin, Porter + Bogusky]] and [[Saatchi & Saatchi]] (New Zealand).
== Jury panel == The jury consists of an international panel of over a world class Creative Leader (2014 Jury Chairman announced as Mike Byrne - Partner / Chief Creative Officer of Anomaly), the best up & coming creative stars from the majority of global advertising agency networks, as previous year's winner of "YoungGuns of the Year".<ref name=bnt_1 />
== Past winners == * 2001 Guy Shelmerdine and Grant Holland (Cliff Freeman & Partners New York) * 2002 Antony Nelson (Saatchi & Saatchi London) * 2003 Trevor Clarence (Terraplane South Africa) * 2004 Travis Sorge (Saatchi & Saatchi Los Angeles) * 2005 Juan Cabral (Fallon London) - most notable for creating and directing [[Cadbury Dairy Milk]]'s [[Gorilla (advertisement)]] in 2007 * 2006 Matt Devine and Luke Crethar (Glue Society Sydney) * 2007 Jeff Anderson and Isaac Silvergate (TBWA Chiat Day New York) * 2008 Craig Allen and Eric Kallman (TBWA Chiat Day New York) * 2009 Michael Canning (Leo Burnett Sydney) * 2010 Douglas Goh (McCann Erickson Malaysia) * 2011 Alexander Nowak and Felix Richter (Y&R New York) * 2012 Rasmus Keger and Morten Halvorsen (R/GA New York) * 2013 Tarik Abdel-Gawad (Bot & Dolly New York)<ref name="ygawardwinner">[http://www.ygaward.com/documents/youngguns_history.pdf YounGuns Award Brief History] Retrieved 2011-10-02</ref>
